While it may not be one of Stanley Kubrick's best films, Full Metal Jacket is distinctly a Kubrick film.  The takes are long and filled with lengthy tracking shots, slow zooms and methodical pans, all traits of his later work.  Dealing with the devastating dehumanization of war on its participants, the film is essentially told in two parts – Marine basic training followed by combat in Vietnam.  The first portion features powerful performances by R. Lee Ermey as the sadistic Sergeant Hartman and Vincent D'Onofrio as the object of Hartman's abuse while the second half deals with Private Joker (Matthew Modine), a Marine journalist covering the war at the time of the Tet Offensive.  Where does the film falter?  Not for one second does the film look or feel like Vietnam, despite the dying palm trees spread around the shooting locations.  As well, the soundtrack (Chapel of Love, Wooly Bully, Surfin' Bird, etc.) is totally out of place and wince-worthy.  All in all, it's a decent movie – just not decent by Kubrick's standards.

Stanley Kubrick was a legendary filmmaker for his vivid storytelling, entertaining movies, thoughtful commentary, long panning shots, The Kubrick Stare close-up shot, and impeccably edited films. His direction is peerless at his peak. This is why it's so odd that Full Metal Jacket is such a lopsided film with questionable editing from Martin Hunter. His cuts in scenes are engaging, but you could easily cut down a half hour of Full Metal Jacket and lose nothing. It's 116 minutes for no reason. Douglas Milsome's cinematography is excellent with steady panning shots revolving around the barracks or along the firing line. The wide shots during the warzone combat in the second half are much shakier. It's no Spartacus.

Vivian Kubrick's score is something of an oddity. Her synth heavy music completely changes and elevates all the training in Full Metal Jacket's first half. On the other hand, her obnoxious drum choices and noises distract from the shootouts instead of making everything tense and suspenseful.

In all, I recommend Full Metal Jacket, but feel free to turn it off halfway.

Private Joker, Matthew Modine, and Gomer Pyle, Vincent D'Onofrio, go through boot camp under the tutelage of Gunnery Sergeant Hartmann, R. Lee Ermey. Hartmann proves to be extremely tough and he turns all of the recruits against Pyle due to his being overweight which causes him to be physically and emotionally abused and ultimately commit a violent act. We jump forward to 1968 in the second half of the film as we see Joker become a journalist for The Stars and Stripes who write military propaganda. His relatively carefree life is interrupted when an attack on his marine base and he and other writers are left to defend themselves amongst the rubble. Eventually they discover that the sniper who murdered one of their friends is just a little girl but Joker is still pushed to kill her at her own request.

The scenes in the film that work best are, in my opinion, those that come in the second half of the film. The first half felt like it was stealing from Catch-22 (1970) and MASH (1970) with the satirical elements it incorporated and while Ermey's performance is deserving of it's iconic status I felt he was a touch overused. The second half settled down a little and chose to satirize propaganda and then show the dark effects of the war on innocent people. I was emotionally impacted by the scenes that feature people being devastated by warfare and while other films show death and destruction better Kubrick at least shows he can make a film in which he is emotionally engaged. This may be a controversial opinion because I understand that a lot of people are big fans of the first half while they think the second drops into mediocrity, I would still tend to disagree.

I suppose another thing I felt was missing from this film was an interesting visual style. Every other Kubrick film looks amazing and you feel as though the director has focused each shot intensely in an attempt to execute his outlandish vision. Cinematographer Douglas Milsome also worked on three of Kubrick's other films so he clearly knows how to make a film look beautiful but this film just looks sort of blah. Even Platoon (1986) looks better than this film and I have many problems with that film relating to how the director deals with the material he is working with. Not every film needs to look incredible to be affecting but a large part of the reason why Kubrick films are so brilliant are their visuals and you expect to see something new and exciting on the screen every time you watch one of his films.

In the end I would say that this film is worth watching even if it's not a masterpiece because it's still post Paths of Glory (1957) Kubrick and we should treasure his work as he only provided us with a few great films but truly great ones at that. Full Metal Jacket is a perfect story about the duality of man, what it means to have individuality and what group mentality does to you. Joker is the character that the audience latches on to because he is the physical embodiment of going through the phase of being individual or to have a group mentality. His decisions throughout the entire movie are determined by his own interest, except for the moments when he does something questionable, beating up Pyle for example. He does this not because he wants to, but because he is encouraged to, he does keep his individuality, portrayed by a peace sign on his chest. When Joker loses his individuality and truly becomes a mindless killing machine, his peace emblem is covered, he has lost his individuality. This moment is perhaps one of the greatest moments in cinema history and the entire movie drives towards showing this moment. All of the events with Pyle becoming insane, the soldier in the helicopter shooting innocent women and children and the U.S. soldiers having sex with Vietnamese prostitutes, while Joker is sitting of to the side saying nothing, are in direct correlation with the ending scene. This is really what makes this movie a great piece of cinema. Clear direction and a focused script really drive the narrative and the cinematography was also great. Stanley Kubrick has made many movies that people either love or hate, A Clockwork Orange, 2001: A Space Odyssey, Eyes Wide Shut, movies that are not very popular but are liked by some people, Barry Lyndon, Dr. Strangelove, Paths of Glory, and there are his movies that everyone pretty much loves, The Shining, and the movie I will be reviewing today, Full Metal Jacket. I picked this up at my local library on blu ray and watched it on a friday night. On the way home, my dad asked me what movie I got, I showed him the blu ray, and he was like "that's a very good movie" and yeah that was all. Watching Full Metal Jacket, it didn't remind me of other good war films I've seen. It was very different from Saving Private Ryan, Dunkirk, Hacksaw Ridge, it is really unique, probably the most unique war film I've ever seen. The storytelling and the elements in the story about the Vietnam war really made it raw. That's how I'd describe the movie, raw. R. Lee Ermey really gave one of the best performances in history in this movie, in my opinion. Even though he was on screen for about 15 minutes, he made those 15 minutes so intense, so great, and gives the movie dark comedic scenes. I think his performance as Sgt. Hartman is one of the best performances of all time. Vincent D'Onofrio's performance as a private that struggles in the beginning of the movie because of military training camp being too hard for him, and R. Lee Ermey's character being a hard mentor, challenging Vincent D'Onofrio's character physically and mentally, it is really compelling stuff. The part where he shoots Sgt. Hartman, then shoots himself, is one of the most jaw dropping scenes of all time. The look on Vincent D'Onofrio's face in that scene haunted me for the rest of that night. There is also another main character in this movie named Joker, (that's his nickname). He is in this military camp with Vincent D'Onofrio's character, and he goes through this camp, watching horrific things happen, you really get into the shoes of this character. The next acts of this movie is Joker going to Vietnam and experiencing the war. This part of the movie was really different from the first part back on Parris Island. A lot of people thought this 2nd part of the movie was not as good as the first part, but I thought both parts were great. The Vietnam war was portrayed so rough and raw in this movie, it was pretty breathtaking. The message/allegory of this story was so beautiful and 100% true, it really makes me look at war differently. The only issue I have with this movie is that I thought the movie really dragged at the middle of the film. Not much things were going on, there wasn't really much of a direction either, it just kind of felt like the story was going nowhere. Other than that, I thought this movie was really good. 9/10

This film is one of the first that comes to mind when thinking of all of Kubrick's masterpieces, and it's not hard to see why. For starters, the setting brilliantly captures the tense atmosphere of Marine Corps training to prepare for war. This is best demonstrated when looking at the character Leonard Lawrence, better known as Private Pyle. Over the course of the first half of the film, Sargent Hartman, the brutal drill instructor, belittles him for being slow-witted and overall just not prepared for battle. To make matters worse he decides to punish the rest of the Marines for Pyle's mistakes. This is first seen when Pyle smuggles a doughnut because he could not deal with the feeling of hunger. Hartman retaliates by forcing the entire cabin to do intense exercises, causing them all to dislike Pyle. Tired of all of Pyle's screw ups, the entire bunk gives Pyle a beating. By each getting a towel, filling it with a bar of soap, and proceeding to hit him in the stomach repeatedly while others hold him down. After feeling immense pain and realizing that everyone hates him, Pyle loses all emotion and becomes a killing machine. Hartman and the others are very proud of him and all seems well until the next night. Private Joker, one of Pyle's fellow Marines, hears a noise in the restroom and decides to investigate only to find Pyle loading a rifle. Joker tells Pyle to go back to sleep and put his rifle away or else they will be in a world of shit. Pyle responds with, "I'm already in a world of shit!", and proceeds to repeat various chants that were spoken on their marches. After hearing all of the shouting Hartman storms in and proceeds to yell at Pyle and belittle him more. Void of all emotion and thought, Pyle shoots Hartman in the chest, killing him. Realizing what he had done, Pyle spends a few minutes reflecting, only before putting the rifle in his mouth and blowing his brains out. While all of this is very malicious and depressing, it is very realistic and corresponds to the tense environment of war to the point that it is almost beautiful. The training portion of the film is one of my favorite parts of any movie to this date earning this movie an easy five star rating. The section that illustrates war in Vietnam is also well made, but is honestly quite forgettable when looking at the first half of the film. Yet, this is still a movie that I would recommend to anyone, whether they typically enjoy films of this genre.

Frankly, I loved the film. It was a little disorienting, in that there are essentially two different parts of the film. I got so invested in Pyle's story and watching that evolve, that I found myself having to readjust when the film segued into following Joker's story. Up until Pyle shot himself, I had assumed that this story was about Pyle. It was interesting to me that the perspective seemed to change in each part of the film. The first part seemed to be more from Pyle's perspective, to then set up the second part of the film being from Joker's perspective. It made me feel intrigued by the psyche of the men in the military. It made me also feel concerned for how the constant negating and invalidating affects these men. The pace of the film was also interesting. Things sort of seemed to have a slow build in the beginning up until Pyle's emotional turn took place. For me, the same thing happened in the second part of the film when Joker and his crew were backed into a corner with the Vietnamese. In both parts of the film, it was interesting that there was this slower-paced nonchalant approach to setting up these stories, however, once things got going we very much-so "zoomed in" to the conflict in the story and what was going on. Music was a big part of the movie, however, in these moments Kubrick chose to have no, or very little, music be a part of them. For me, it allowed me to be more attentive to what was going on and what was at stake.

Full Metal Jacket is not just about war, but rather the psychology behind it. A smart move from the legend that was Stanley Kubrick. We've all seen many war films, a genre that is well explored from a variety of different conflicts. Full Metal Jacket however chooses to go behind the scenes and focus on the training process that changes well intentioned men into trained lethal killers. You could easily split this in half and have two separate films, the first half being more psychologically charged whereas the latter showcasing the brutality of warfare. A ridiculously serious drill sergeant practically bullying a trainee marine so harshly that it slowly turns him into an unstable psychopath. That right there, was some really good psychology and made the film so much more interesting. Sure the Vietnam War scenes were depicted with a substantial amount of fire, blood and guns but it was the first half that really captivated me. Vincent D'Onofrio was the stand out for me, both convincing and expressive through his face. Matthew Modine was good, probably his best performance. Lee Ermey deserves recognition just for somehow managing to not lose his voice from all the shouting. Characterisation was present, perhaps not fully fleshed out as I would like but was just enough for me to care about them. Yet again though, it's the technical marvel that wins...Stanley Kubrick. His directing style is so damn flawless. The nice clean long takes, actors looking directly into the camera, slow motion deaths (particularly in the sniper shootout)...he is just phenomenal. Script was sharp as well. A great section of dialogue where our lead character wears a peace badge and a helmet that says "born to kill" for which he describes represents the duality of man. That really stuck with me. So whilst it might feel like two separate films (due to that ridiculously quick transition), it's hard not to appreciate everything that's shown to us. Another hit from Mr. Kubrick.

But it's hard to call this a war film, as there's no one to root for, or sympathize with, or identify with.  This is certainly a Kubrick film: masterfully crafted and interesting with naturalistic performances and provocative images.  But it's also something less: in its negativity and cynicism and dehuminization, it's more of a nihilist jaunt through violence and depravity than an artistic statement.  There's no real tragedy, only the fate of poor Gomer Pyle, probably the unique spirit that can't survive in the army.  Instead of hinting at his themes, Kubrick has his "Joker" shout them at you, informing his conversant that the peace symbol and "born to kill" on his helmet represents "the duality of man".  

Perhaps Full Metal Jacket is about nothing more than how humans can kill and be killed.  Or perhaps it's a meandering and ultimately toothless attempt to satirize war by having monstrous men do monstrous things on camera.  But what we'll never know is why Kubrick slowed down so suddenly, how the man who once wished to film Napoleon with 50,000 real soldiers settled for R Lee Ermey slinging violent language at young men.  How can the same man who made 2001 make Full Metal Jacket after Apocalypse Now and The Deer Hunter already existed?  What happened to the compelling and heroic humanity of Paths of Glory, or unstoppable craftsman of The Shining?  It's safe to say we'll never know.  

But as for Full Metal Jacket, there's blood, there's yelling and there's death.  There's men who are mere cartoons of men, foreigners who amount to nothing more than whores and cowardly snipers.  Lacking the dynamism and sheer brilliance and beauty of every Kubrick film from Paths of Glory to The Shining, Full Metal Jacket just doesn't measure up.  You'll laugh at first, until you realize that a man is being tortured on screen, and then you'll hate the rest of them, and you might just wish that they all die, or better, that they all get killed, which is apparently all that humans can do according to this movie.

Apparently my general opinions on this movie are pretty common: I loved the first half and enjoyed the second half a little less. There's a number of reasons for why, but I think the main one is that the first half has this propulsive quality to it that the second half just lacks.

Every scene in the first half just zips by because of the drill instructor Sgt. Hartman, who just never lets up, screaming constantly so it's impossible to look away even for a second (this is especially because R. Lee Ermey is so magnetic in the role). The pacing of the first half feels flawless; the audience still needs to feel small moments of reprieve out of necessity, and so those are provided for in the scenes between Pyle and Joker. You really feel for Pyle in those scenes, and get this sense that he's a gentle giant, this poor ignorant guy who just needs someone to be there for him when he's relentlessly tortured by Hartman. Joker provides that kind relief that Pyle (and the audience) needs in between exhausting scenes with Hartman. And then that all ends when Pyle is assaulted by his fellow Marine volunteers, and Joker reluctantly takes part. It's pretty tragic because Joker doesn't realize at the time that if he had stood up for Pyle, if he'd stuck by him in his hardest moments, maybe what inevitably happens wouldn't have happened. And yeah, we haven't even talked about that final scene, in which Pyle kills Hartman and then himself. Just crazy, man. I sort of saw it coming that he would go crazy, but I somehow thought the movie wouldn't go there, and it did.

The second half has a lot of standout images and dialogue that make it far from pointless. Adam Baldwin's character, Animal Mother, is an interesting guy because it's pretty damn heartless until the end, when he vows to get revenge on the sniper who killed his friends, and then in the last scene, when he's disgusted by the thought of killing a little girl. There are some funny lines, like Joker's talk about the peace sign and the 'born to kill' writing representing the 'duality of man,' and there are some interesting, thematically strong interludes, like when one soldier reveals that the guy sitting next to him under a blanket is a dead Vietnamese soldier, brought back as some sort of sick prize. All of these moments of originality and thematic potency are especially powerful because of Stanley Kubrick's direction. He shoves you into all of these scenes and forces you to confront them; when Rafterman records the man with the pet Vietcong carcass on camera, we see it from the camera's point of view, so it's like the twisted soldier is telling us directly. There are a lot of moments like that in the movie, when people seem to be staring right at us, especially at the end, when the wounded sniper girl looks up at us and begs us to shoot her. And then there's the whole recurring idea of the 'thousand yard stare,' and Joker's final action in killing the young girl and achieving that stare. His choice to kill her, while merciful in a way, is dark because we've seen him resisting darkness the whole movie, and we've hoped that maybe he could make up for his role in Pyle's bullying. But finally he kills the girl, and it's ostensibly merciful, but it sure looks like execution to us.

So there are a lot of images in the second half that are great and carry a lot of emotional and satirical heft, even if that meaning is as reductive as "war sucks," something that tons of movies, like Apocalypse Now, have already done. And the shapelessness that makes me not like the second half as much has been said to have a point. War, after all, is shapeless and confusing and chaotic and messy. Still, just because a movie's unpleasant (exaggerating for effect here) structure and pacing are that way for the express purpose of making a point doesn't mean they're enjoyable on a shallow level, and I like my movies to be at least somewhat entertaining on a shallow level. There's a ruthless efficiency to the first half that's inevitably missed in the second level, even if the formal elements continue to support the tone of the respective sections.

Overall, this was a movie I really enjoyed, with a kickass, tragic first half with a unique setting in a boot camp, and a second half that was a little less enjoyable because of its slow-paced shapelessness and the absence of Ermey and Vincent D'Onofrio. Still, there were enough vivid images and nice dialogue throughout the second half that it made up for most of its shortcomings and delivered an adequate second half to an ambitious, dark story.

Even though Full Metal Jacket was made in 1987, Director Stanley Kubrick had already been around for a long time--for example, he's known for filming the largely satirical Dr. Strangelove in the early 60s. His filming ingenuity only got better as time went on, and Full Metal Jacket is proof of this fact. In this movie, Kubrick relied heavily on a soundtrack to tell the narrative through the technique of satire. I believe that this soundtrack is used to establish an ironical relationship between the audience and the characters in the movie. In other words, Kubrick uses the soundtrack as an ironic plot device. For example, the choice to use "The Chapel of Love" while the men are at war serves to either make fun of or emphasize the desperate attitudes of some of the soldiers experiencing post-traumatic stress. In other words, the movie indirectly makes fun of steadfast patriotism when war instead really promises mental insanity.

Review In A Nutshell:

When we think of war, the images that come to our head are the smoke that slowly breathes out of a fired rifle, the red blood that stains the green uniform, the flash of an exploding grenade; these are dark images that fill the puzzle of war's brutality and horror, but what these images do not show is the horrors that lurk underneath; the human spirit fractured in order to fulfil their duty as soldiers. Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket stands along with films like Apocalypse Now, The Thin Red Line, and Paths of Glory where war is seen through the eyes of the soldiers and how their experiences have affected them internally; the unseen soul.

The film begins with the sight of men sitting down and having their hair shaved completely off with faces of both sadness and uncertainty. It is the U.S. Marine's first step in attempting to take what is most precious of them, their identities. It is the idea that each and every one of these soldiers will be identical fighting machines, despite the drill instructor denying this, to strip them completely of what they were and instil a new perspective on yourself, your brothers, and your enemies. The film then takes us to the intimidating introduction of their drill instructor, Sergeant Hartman, a man who response only to sheer volume and intensity, constantly searching for flaws and anomalies in the soldiers' systems and destroying them little by little. This is also where we get to see these soldiers further lose themselves, through the replacement of their names with nicknames that are far from who they really are, aside from maybe Joker, whom which probably impressed the Sergeant despite his disrespect. During this introduction is also the time where the audience is formally introduced to Leonard Lawrence, who is better known in the camp as Gomer Pyle, as a connection to his inherent dimwittedness and innocence; he becomes the Sergeant immediate target because he knows Gomes Pyle is not right for the corps but since he is already present and unlikely to quit, he has to do the best he can to push him to his highest limits. Gomer Pyle's journey through the training is one of the most terrifying experiences I have ever seen, showing how a fresh young face could fall so low in human spirit; a soul that has suffered psychological and emotional torment, betrayal from his once loyal and respected brothers, having to endure demanding and straining physical training, it all adds up in shaping what he would ultimately become, a soulless monster. The end of this half delivered one of the most gasping moments of the entire film, the bathroom massacre. A slow moving Joker flashes his light on Gomer Pyle, revealing him in possession of a live cartridge that is then locked and loaded into his rifle. It is clear that the training he has endured has pushed him too far, deprived of happiness and consciousness, knowing only his duty as a marine corps, to kill. It is the horrifying image of his wicked stare that shivers the audience's bones, not the loaded rifle itself; it is the idea that he has gone too far to find salvation, and it was only in the sound of his once precious name that a glimmer came to his eye and decides to end himself once and for all, sparing Joker's life. It is a moment that stays with you long after the film ends, reminding you of the many Gopher Pyles out there walking and causing pain to those undeserving of it.

The second half of the film then turns to the big stage, Vietnam and the war that deeply affected everyone that took part in it. It still follows in the eyes of Joker who works as a correspondent for an American newspaper, Stars and Stripes, which aimed to report news, boost soldier morale, and sway the minds of those unconvinced of America's involvement in the war; it is an element that Kubrick only covers minimally, but hearing it spoke volumes to me; displaying more of what the war really is, without having to actually show it. It would have been fantastic if Kubrick further covered it. After a suicide squad attempting to infiltrate their base, Joker was assigned to the "shit" with his photographer Rafterman, and from there we experience the true nature of soldier warfare; the unpredictability, the paranoia, the destruction that surrounds them, all coming to together to slowly destroy the innocent mind of our protagonist; a person who had a sense of balance, surviving the war with killing in his head, "Born to Kill", and forgiveness in his heart, the peace symbol, retaining that part of himself that keeps him sane. The film subtly throughout this half, question the true agenda of the soldier's stay in Vietnam, told from the perspective of the soldiers themselves through documentary-like interviews that show honest and thoughtful responses. The film then leads to a gripping climax of a sniper picking off their platoon, one by one. It is a tense situation that ends with harrowing imagery. It is revealed that the sniper is just a young girl, and through this Kubrick scares us with the idea that children were raised and trained in order to fight for their causes, youth losing its innocence far too early, wanting her life to end rather than ask for medical attention; it is a frightening scene that shows just how damaged our world is. Ending the film, is a slightly touching scene of soldiers marching in the night, singing out loud a song from their beloved childhood; holding tight a piece of themselves in order to get through god-awful war.

Full Metal Jacket may not be the most obvious film in regards to Kubrick's sense of visual and audible flair, but the film's grounded visual take on the war is meaningful and terrifying. During the film's first half, it captures the uniform and tightness of military training, a zone where anarchy and natural movements are absent. During interior scenes, we get a layer of darkness that connects with the gradual loss of the souls of its subjects, coming off more like a mental asylum rather than a barrack; very few films could capture this without becoming too stylish in its imagery. The second half of the film opens up with a larger canvas, displaying the destructive conditions of the war; with sights of crumbling buildings, flaming interiors, and abundance of dirt. The film still manages to be a spectacle without forgetting the film's most important subjects, the characters. The second half spends a fair amount of time with the camera closer to the ground, along the feet of the soldiers, like as if we were trying to take cover from enemy fire, a paranoia of having our heads stand too high; it maintains a sense of uneasiness that correlates with the emotions of its characters. Kubrick almost strips the whole film with vibrant colours, keeping the film feeling deathly and soul crushing; pushing dark greens and dusty browns, the colours that immediately bring to mind the conditions of war.

The haunting score by Vivian Kubrick, under the alias of Abigail Mead, dominates the film's scenes through generating dark and atmospheric emotions that elevate the film's themes and tension; just listen to the rumbling seedy tones during the bathroom massacre. The same goes for the sniper sequence, with music that crawls under our skin and feeds dark and fracturing emotions. The combination of Kubrick's score and Americana soundtrack gave the film that sense of balance and flavour, coming off as different from the other films that cover the same ground; it never tries to over-dramatize its scenes, instead the score reaches for the darker depths of the film's characters without drama elevation, while the soundtracks are present to create a hilarious satire of America's presence in the war.

Matthew Modine is the film's protagonist, Private Joker, but I felt his performance was a bit underwhelming as compared to others that have led in a Kubrick film; the writing certainly makes his role feel interesting but his performance rarely ever elevates it. Kubrick always had a cold detachment. Whether it be focusing on the exploitation of soldiers from their peers in "Paths of Glory" or laughing to the nuclear gallows with "Dr. Strangelove," it was obvious that Kubrick preferred cynicism over warmth. 'Full Metal Jacket' most certainly follows Kubrick's cynical perception, a movie that reflects the Marine Corps deconstruction of the human being to become a natural born killer. Thematically, Kubrick's anti-war message is one that has been told time and time again. However, and with the help of the hilarious Sergeant Hartman (Ermey) - a character that continually shouts disgusting simile's and metaphors that creates an enjoyable balance of dark humour - Kubrick's deliverance of this recycled message is undeniably riveting. Besides Ermey's performance, Kubrick's ability as craftsman most certainly elevates the somewhat tiresome material. Not only is the direction spot on but also the meticulous touches to the lighting and music that contribute to overall harrowing affect (especially during the sequence where Pyle commits suicide; the lighting, the direction and music all combine perfectly to reflect the descent into violent madness). 

However, while these themes are portrayed with power, there are times where you feel Kubrick is being too cynical or simply too simplistic. Surely all Marine Corps are not systematic to point that there is no room for some gesture of humour or characterization? I know Kubrick is representing the  deconstruction of humane qualities contributed from war, but such a focus makes the story at times rather dull (this is quite noticeable in the second half with the spark of the Ermey missing and the audience are left with a group of uninteresting cold-blooded killing machines). Besides these shortcomings in the second half, Kubrick's direction of Nam's battlefields are once again riveting. Revisiting the tracking shots he adopted in 'Paths of Glory,' Kubrick places the camera in a position so the audience are invited into the films battle depictions against the backdrop of the beautiful destructive scenery. Rather than giving the audience the benefit of an omnipresent vision, Kubrick situates the audience in the soldiers position which creates a realistic feel that many war films seem to lack. Fundamentally, while Kubrick's vision at times is too cynical, "Full Metal Jacket" features a great amount of enjoyable black humour and a craftsman at the top of his game.

- 'Full Metal Jacket' is a 1987 war film directed and produced by Stanley Kubrick (The Shining, Eyes Wide Shut). The film is based on the novel 'The Short Timers' by Gustaph Hasford and portraits the training and actual combat action of some young marines during the Vietnam War. Kubrick is a master in storytelling by showing hard facts mixed with well-chosen music. A couple of scenes will be glued to your memory. This 'Full Metal Jacket' is a must-see classic. Starring Matthew Modine (The Transporter 2, Weeds), Adam Baldwin (Predator 2, Independence Day), Vincint D'Onofrio (Men in Black, The Cell) and R. Lee Ermey (The Texas Chainsaw remakes, Willard). 

1967, Senior Drill Instructor Gunnery Sergeant Hartman (Ermey) trains a load of U.S. Marine Corps recruits in their boot camp. His iron fist will discipline the boys. One of them is James Davis (Modine), who is given the nickname 'Joker'. He dares to take a stand and considered to be in charge of his fellow recruits. Another is the clumsy overweight Leonard Lawrence (D'Onofrio) who earns the nickname 'Gomer Pyle'. He suffers the most from Hartman's boot camp training. With some help from 'Joker', he does seem to improve. But when Hartman discovers that 'Gomer Pyle' has stashed away a jelly doughnut: the whole squad is punished for his deeds...

The following year, 'Joker' has become a war correspondent at the Vietnam War. When the Tet Offensive kicks in, he joins a platoon of Marines on a deadly mission. There he sees one of his of boot camp mates and meets machine gunner 'Animal Mother' (Baldwin). Will they live to tell the tale?

Second half isn't that interesting, but this is undoubtedly a Stanley Kubrick masterpiece.  Based off The Short-Timers, a semi-autobiographical book by Gustav Hasford, Full Metal Jacket follows a US Marine platoon going through training, later transitioning its focus to two Marines of the platoon in the Tet Offensive during the Vietnam War.  The film does tons of detail exploring the steps that are taken into becoming a Marine, including following orders correctly, moving through obstacles quickly and flawlessly, remaining organized, preparing weapons correctly, and remaining close to the squad the soldier is assigned to.  The film, like many masterful war films, uses tons of graphic violence and personal conflict in order to add realism and humanity to the story in order to prevent Full Metal Jacket from going into generic war film territory.  Stanley Kubrick uses his unbelievable genius to craft a film that says "war".  He does an incredible job by giving audiences heart breaking battle sequences that also shock them rather than entertain them (thank God, because war is disgraceful).  Kubrick, Michael Herr, and author Hasford craft a script that expands Part I, and contains elements of Part II and III, yet omits Part III.  Part II isn't that engaging or as interesting or psychologically disturbing as Part I, but is still a key element to the story, even if it's message isn't that great.  The acting is stellar, most particularly R. Lee Ermey as Gunnery Sergeant Hartman, a ruthless, mean, foul-mouthed drill instructor who actually was played by a US Marine drill instructor who was in service during the Vietnam War, and Vincent D'Onofrio as Private Leonard "Gomer Pyle" Lawrence, an overweight, clumsy, incompetent, slow-witted recruit who in fact becomes the focus for Sergeant Hartman for his flaws.  In fact, R. Lee Ermey's scene where he chewed out the new recruits was mostly improvised, despite the fact that Kubrick never allowed his actors to improvise, although he allowed a few to do that, R. Lee Ermey's being one of them, which helped show off the brutality of his character, especially to D'Onofrio's Pyle.  In fact, this scene should've gotten him an Oscar nod, same goes for D'Onofrio.  Vincent is able to capture the recruit going from a troubled man, to an insane, creepy, and flawless recruit whose unpredictable in every corner.  The change in D'Onofrio's character shows that people can change even before they go to war (nonviolence anyone?), and that training can have negative implications in them and/or their platoon.  A must-see, especially for anyone who's against war.

Stanley Kubrick's take on novel The Short Timers, is in equal amounts hilarious and haunting, although very much a film of 2 halves, this outing does offer up a whole bunch of satire, violence and punch for its buck, but sadistically manages to inject some ferocious comedy into the mix. We follow a bunch of new recruits in the American marine core, during the Vietnam war, it opens light heartedly enough, country music highlighting a montage of hair shaving and outstandingly whitty monologues from Lee Emery as the iconic Gunnery Sgt Harmen, howeven soon the trials of war and the pressure and treatment of cadets become too much for some members. Flash forward some time from that and we are stuck with a few of the team as they plough through Vietnam, killing innocents and making videos like superstars. If that seems like a huge leap in synopsis its because this is very much a lop sided film. The first section is tremendous, up there with some of his best work, brilliant cinematography with continual moving shots, give the film a subtle sense of pace and Lee Emery's performance alone with Vincent D'Onofrio totally roll the ball forward, giving us a training session worth remembering. It manages to balance everything right, comedy, brutality and satire all with an underlying disgust as the sequence comes to a brutal conclusion. Kubrick's film then jettisons us forward with little mention of anything prior apart from the characters of Private Joker, Matthew Modine and Private Cowboy, Arliss Howard. Here we the film turns fully satirical, honing in on how biased the american propaganda was that not even their own troops fully understood why they were there, in a round about way summing up what the rest of the world was thinking at the time. It's not that the second half is bad, quite the opposite but put side by side with the first and it is so mismatched you cant help but be jolted out the movie for multiple viewings. It feels almost like the first section should be the entire movie, however with its length, Kubrick feels the need to bundle in the next part, either that or the complete shift in tone is intended to make us feel the way we do. Regardless it is jolting and takes a lot of repeat viewing until getting used to the step. The entire film looks, sounds and illuminates perfectly, the subtle music throughout the piece give a sense of time, pace and emotion, while bookended with iconic, of the time songs. The war torn Vietnam is also outstandingly realized, industrial wastelands strew with fire up the side of buildings as snipers and booby traps lay waste to soldiers, really give a sense of guerilla warfare. Yet the film isnt perfect, the majority of characters are very one note and alienating. This adds a peculiar air to the piece but at times seems a little jarring, there at times seems like there is a little too much filler, the film packs such a punch, however its so prolonged that the effects start to wear off after the hour mark. Its brilliant and fun and diabolical all at the same time, its just not the tightest effort ever committed to cinema, which is a shame because when this film is good, it is really fucking good.

War is not worth wasting our youth

Full Metal Jacket is about the idea that war is not worth wasting our youth. It tries to prove this with two stories: the first is the marines training for deployment, the second is the marines in action in Vietnam.

The first story, the marines training for deployment, is told with two external plots: that of the not so bright marine Pyle trying to finish boot camp and the second is the entire class of marines trying to graduate. The class of marines succeed in graduating, but Pyle does not. He goes crazy after the harsh treatment meant to harden him to become a killer and commits suicide. So this story gets to the point that preparing for war is inhumane and not worth wasting our youth.

The second story is about the marines fighting to win the war in Vietnam. This is told with two plots: that of winning the war and the second of the declining morality of the marines. The war is not won, it ends ambiguously as the marines win a small insignificant battle and return to camp while the morality of the marines shows a constant decline and ends with our hero committing murder.

The movie is a great testament to the anti-war movement and a visual essay on the meaninglessness of war. But it is not a very engaging story. The first half of the movie makes a tight dramatic point that training marines to be killer has some inhumane consequences and proves it with Pyle's suicide. But the second half doesn't have an overall story arc to hang its hat on. The status of the main external plot of winning the war is left ambiguous. So the moral decline of our hero who has to commit murder at the end doesn't create as much meaning since the murder doesn't get us any further in winning the war.

One can argue that that's the point of the movie, is that these atrocities are senseless and meaningless. And that is true. But in terms of a dramatic story, the meaning of the action is lost because the filmmakers abhorred making winning the war into any resemblance of a real plot.

In the first half of the movie, Pyle's suicide is juxtaposed with the success of class of marines all graduating. Thus it makes the point that his suicide is not worth it for us to successfully train marines. But in the second half of the movie, Joker commits murder but this action is not juxtaposed with progression of any other plot. So the action loses the chance to create meaning through a consequence for his actions. It feels like the movie was cut off without any real resolution, like another 15 minutes were missing.

Full Metal Jacket is a unique offering in the world of war films: an apolitical two-segmented movie that depicts the dehumanizing training that turns Marine recruits into killers and their subsequent service in the Vietnam War during the Tet Offensive. Add this unique nature with memorable characters and moments as well as an insightful examination of military training and you have an instant classic.

The film is split in two very distinct portions: training and warfare. The first section depicts potential Marines undergoing brutal training at Parris Island prior to deployment in Vietnam in 1968. Here, the recruits are subject to the whims and desensitizing tactics of their tough drill instructor (portrayed by former USMC Gunnery Sergeant R. Lee Ermey in a legendary performance). After the completion of boot camp, the film changes direction to follow Stars and Stripes reporter "Joker" (Matthew Modine) as he takes part in the Tet Offensive and the Battle of Hue City in Vietnam. The first is more famous and slightly better and more engaging than the second, but both are enjoyable and keep you on the edge of your seat.

For me, the film needs to be memorable in order for me to like it AND watch it more than once. That happens due to great characters and unforgettable moments, and Full Metal Jacket provides both. For characters, there is a cast of rough, tough, individual Leathernecks such as independent, duality-loving, combat seeking "Joker", well-meaning, slightly dim, overweight "Gomer Pyle", nihilistic, aggressive "Animal Mother" and several others. What will you remember about this movie? An infamous opening sequence featuring a funny and coarse introduction from Gunny Hartman, a frequently-quoted Vietnamese prostitute, an insensitive, unstable, highly quotable door-gunner, and several profane boot camp cadences, along with many other instances. 

The most powerful theme of Full Metal Jacket (and its difference from other war films) is its study of military indoctrination. In the movie, indoctrination provides two results: successful transformation into a Marine and a killer, or total failure resulting in a psychological time bomb. Joker is the former: he begins as a standout recruit, the one who refuses to hold back his insightful, sardonic comments even at the expense of rebuke or Gunny Hartman's fist and rises to become platoon leader during boot camp. In Vietnam, he is the reporter who wears a helmet saying "Natural Born Killer" and a peace symbol and seeks the gritty truth at the behest of his superiors, who want to boost moral even if it means tweaking news headlines. By the end of the film, Joker becomes a combat veteran, witness to the brutality of war and difficult moral decisions and bearing the "thousand-mile stare", his mark as a killer. Pyle, on the other hand, finds himself the ultimate target of Hartman's wrath due to his weight and incompetence. His failure throughout boot camp and the constant psychological and physical abuse he endures leads to tragedy for him and the platoon.

Full Metal Jacket is gritty and unflinching, and while not as violent or containing as much combat as other war films, there is brutality nonetheless. However, it is an excellent war film that I consider one of the best out there and one that you will certainly not forget.

War! Huh! What is it good for? Okay, you get the shtick. It was roughly ten years after Vietnam War that the Stanley Kubrick film Full Metal Jacket was released. At this point, two landmark war films about the same war were already released, with universal acclaim: Francis Ford Coppola's Apocalypse Now and Oliver Stone's Platoon. Somehow, Kubrick manages to plow out the inevitable comparisons to such films by creating an equally effective war film. Need not worry. The rest of the review will not be answering, "What makes this so different from the others?"
Based on the novel The Short-Timers by Gustav Hasford, the film primarily follows, and is narrated by, a fierce journalist simply known as Joker (Matthew Modine). We witness his, along with various other U.S. Marines', endeavors through boot camp on Parris Island and brutal warfare in 'Nam. Leading the platoon of privates on Parris Island is a no-nonsense (mind you, that is an understatement) drill sergeant known as Hartman (R. Lee Ermey). Among Joker's fellow comrades are Cowboy (Arliss Howard), Snowball (Peter Edmund), and Gomer Pyle (Vincent D'Onofrio). Throughout the boot camp process, Hartman trains his men to grow an instinct to kill or retaliate, lest they land themselves into, "a world of shit." Immediately following all training events are the Joker's mishaps in Vietnam with Rafter Man (Kevyn Howard), Animal Mother (Adam Baldwin), Touchdown (Ed O'Ross), and even an old friend from the island. These mishaps range from TV newscasts and Vietnamese hookers to deadly battles with guerrilla fighters and snipers.
A war film under the two-hour mark is inevitably packing a lot into the punch, and somehow, the whole film comes together remarkably, by the end (which plays out with one of the many hilarious chants sung throughout the film). By the time the Joker is in Vietnam, he bears a peace button and a helmet with the words, "Born to Kill," written on it. When questioned about this combination of attire, the Joker explains that it relates to the duality of man. This duality of man is the essence upon that the entire film touches. Understand that, during Vietnam War, not every soldier volunteered for the job. The draft forced hundreds of thousands of U.S. civilians to throw away their lives in order to kill for peace. What a joke, that is. Joker, perhaps one of the many who was drafted, decided to make a social statement by wearing both the button and the helmet. That is one example of many in the film, where writer and director Stanley Kubrick throws just enough pieces of the puzzle at you, for you to conceive of the rest through some thought. Again, it is a remarkable job on Kubrick's part.
Matthew Modine gives as much as the film allows him to give for his performance as Joker. He is clearly caught in this duality of man throughout the entire film, in instances such as wailing a wrapped bar of soap on Pyle's belly to nobly burying or killing those of any side of the battle. While most of the soldiers have had their minds wiped clean of any morality, Joker still has a tight grip on the peaceful side of man. Admittedly, most of these perceptions are given by how Kubrick shot and wrote certain scenes, but Modine does well in those instances where a normal soldier would act on his instinct, while instead he stands, almost stunned by his uncertainty on which side of the duality to follow.
Other Marines, such as Adam Baldwin and Arliss Howard, play their parts with passable conviction, but the two actors who truly stand out from the film are Vincent D'Onofrio and R. Lee Ermey. You may have heard that the boot camp scenes are much stronger than all that follows. In terms of overall power, I cannot concur, but acting-wise, I would absolutely agree. Without giving too much away, these two solely have more screen time than Joker does during the training process (which occupies a little under half of the film's duration). As previously mentioned, Sergeant Hartman does not put up with anyone's bullshit. He will squeeze your testicles until they pop and grow into bigger, stronger ones. Here is my personal favourite Hartman quip, which Ermey improvised: "I bet you're the kind of guy who'd fuck a guy in the ass and not even have the goddamn common courtesy to give him a reach around." You do not fuck with Hartman. To be fair, R. Lee Ermey was a retired drill instructor who eventually landed the role of Hartman, after working as a technical advisor for the film. He was perfect for the role and it certainly showed.

7 years after The Shining (1980), Stanley Kubrick returned, and this time, he'd made a Vietnam War film, sadly it came out around the same time as Platoon (1986) and Hamburger Hill (1987), which dinted it's box-office. But, it's still one of the best Vietnam war films ever made, and despite what some people say, the second half of the film in Vietnam is just as powerful as the explosive first part. In Parris Island in North Carolina in 1967, a group of privates including Joker (Matthew Modine), Pyle (Vincent D'Onofrio) and Cowboy (Arliss Howard) are placed under the command of Gunnery Sergeant Hartman (R. Lee Ermey), who is brutal and draconian. He particually picks on the bumbling Pyle, who can't seem to anything right, but just as it looks like Pyle is starting to show improvement, he goes psycho. A few months later, Joker is in Vietnam and writing for Stars and Stripes magazine, and he is sent from Da Nang up to Hue just in time for the Tet Offensive, and there he's reunited with Cowboy and he meets the gung-ho Animal Mother (Adam Baldwin). Kubrick would famously not travel outside the UK, so his Vietnam ranges from Sussex and Norfolk to the Docklands or London, and it's bloody convincing too. He gets the best out of his cast, and he handles the action scenes well, with the climactic battle being bloody and quite suspenseful.

Kubrick surprisingly only made two films in the 80s . His follow up to The Shining, well-made as it is, is not without certain flaws and is by no means top-drawer Kubrick. However, it is punctuated with incredible moments in spite of its shortcomings, including a grueling opening-act which details marine training at Parris Island and ends with a hair-raising showdown between a grunt and a gunnery sergeant. Also, the film's bloody climax, with its inconclusive clash between the American forces and an enemy sniper, is simultaneously tense, frightening, ironic and meaningless.

The story (taken from Gustav Hasford's novel The Short-Timers) opens with a bunch of green marine recruits undergoing military training at Parris Island. The drill instructor Gunnery Sergeant Hartman (R. Lee Ermey) is a ruthless, motor-mouthed loony who relentlessly humiliates and desensitizes his boys, so that when he has finally stripped them of their humanity he can rebuild them as single-minded killing machines. Among the bunch is happy-go-lucky Private Joker (Matthew Modine), and the vaguely ridiculous (and ridiculed) Private Pyle (Vincent D'Onofrio). As the recruits near the end of their grueling training regime, Pyle finally cracks under the strain and kills the gunnery sergeant, before turning his gun on himself. The action jumps forward to find Joker on a tour of duty in Vietnam. He is by this point a military journalist who has seen some pretty unpleasant sights during his time in 'Nam (and is divided by his experiences - notice his Born To Kill helmet and his Peace buttoned jacket). The platoon he is part of becomes involved in a street battle in the ruins of Hue City near the film's climax, where they find themselves pinned down and picked off by a female Vietcong sniper. Finally, after much panic and bloodshed, darkness falls and the marines retreat into the night singing the Mickey Mouse March.

Where Kubrick really hits his target is in his depiction of the emotional change within Modine's character, and in his cold and cynical (and authentic) view of the dehumanization that results from being subjected to warfare. Women and children become acceptable targets for the gun-toting soldiers; fear of death gives way to callous indifference; violence becomes normal; horrific deaths and injuries become commonplace to the point of disinterest. No-one in the film can remember the cause they're fighting for or, if they can, they never refer to it. It's just one side versus the other, locked in a costly, savage stalemate, as they enter into violent engagements simply because it's expected of them. The lack of real location work is a problem - Kubrick wouldn't film outside England, so the final gun exchange in Hue City was actually shot in a disused London factory yard, complete with imported palm trees. Also, the film is so intentionally detached from compassion that it becomes hard to relate to anyone in the film. While we're supposed to be shocked by the utter indifference with which people are killed or injured during warfare, the total refusal to present a glimmer of feeling or sympathy makes the film's second half as icily distant as it is bloodthirsty. 

Full Metal Jacket is certainly powerful and potent, but it really is a tale of two halves. Kubrick's specificity in examining the psychology of the solider is so unrelenting and, dare I say militant; the second half doesn't have the same urgency, which leaves the viewer with a sense of deflation.

WAR-The eighth of Kubrick's favorite subjects as foretold by the DVD booklet. 

PLOT:This takes place during the drafts of the Vietnamese War. The plot is pretty basic for a war film, but it's executed greatly, though the first half is way better. 

ACTING:The acting is awesome. Modine does a great job as Joker and D'Onofrio does a brilliant job of Pyle. I can feel the change that takes place in Pyle during his boot camp days. Other great performances were R. Lee Ermey as Sgt. Hartman, Adam Baldwin as Animal Mother, and Kevin Howard as Rafterman.

SCORE:The score was mainly cheesy 80s music and military songs, but they seemed to fit the moods just well.

CAMERAWORK:This had some of Kubrick's famous camerawork in it, but not much.

OTHER CONTENT:This had most of Kubrick's best perks and feels in it, but I can tell what people mean when they say that it's overrated. You can't feel Kubrick's presence in here as much as some of his other works; in fact, if not for the first half of the film, it would have been just another war movie that no one would've acknowledged as anything more than generic, Oscar-bait. It's still a great film, but it just doesn't live up to the potential Kubrick had.

Perhaps Stanley Kubrick's second best film after 2001: A Space Odyssey, Full Metal Jacket is a very cynical and unconventional war film that is less interested in offering a realistic depiction of the nature of war or the army training than it is in the mechanics of how innocent men are turned into ruthless killing machines, and in examining the themes of humanity, authority, individuality, and human destruction. On the first viewing, the film's dual narrative baffles, and when it moves to Vietnam, the viewer is left yearning the first half's brilliant dark humor and R. Lee Ermey's incredibly intense performance (his frenetic opening monologue will never be outdone). But on further viewings the film's intentions become clearer, and rewards the audience. Kubrick was always interested more in ideas than characters (2001 being the perfect example), but Full Metal Jacket gives much space for the characters as well, and in time you learn to feel empathy towards them. While the film is complex, multi-layered, filled with great performances and near-perfect, the duality of the narrative still remains a bit strange, making it feel like Kubrick actually made two films and just blended them together, but not seamlessly enough. But as a whole this is still a great achievement and one of the best war films of all time.

It examines the effects of war on the human psyche, exploring themes of alienation and separation. The characters often refer to their homecoming. We never know what's waiting for them or what lives they want to lead. We never see them as humans. There is character development in FMJ but where are the human qualities that bring characters to life. 

The first half is a visceral experience, the punishment and brainwashing of the marines is provocative, and the minute goes by quickly. Two characters drive this act, their relationship is one that develops and verges on trust, the whole time Leonard is becoming the "killer" Gunnery Sgt. Hartman want him to be while simultaneously being brainwashed. The devastating affect the process has on Leonard leads him to kill himself and the Gunnery Sgt. Here Kubrick is telling us about the harsh transformation of an ordinary man who becomes a killer, it's an unnatural transformation. Leonard's arc is a metaphor for how unnatural war is as a whole, especially for the human mind. Kubrick isn't just telling us war is a bad thing, it's an abnormal thing. The repeated marches suggest the monotony of the craft, perhaps the mindless repetition plays a part in the solder's alienation.

The second  half is a grand mess, it has no emotional resonance nor structure. For a director is renowned for precise planning, Kubrick's genius is absent in the second half. It's completely disorganized and without an objective. 

The first half is enough to carry the film to a positive rating, for it has substance and style, both evenly balanced. There's a beautiful silhouette of the solder's climbing an obstacle, and the imposing Gunnery Sgt. Hartman is too charismatic to ignore. The second half is very disappointing, Kubrick obviously tries to maintain his themes but they are too enigmatic. The audience has nothing to care about.

Kubrick's films all explore dehumanising conditions to some degree, that he was able to do so in many disparate genres was a testament to his skill and obsession, but how war takes identity from you was the subject he kept coming back to, accounting for nearly a third of his films. Full Metal Jacket is perhaps his most condemning of war and it may be his most effective and believable since Fear and Desire. It's easy to think that its specific setting in a war where the soldiers don't have a grip on reality, treating it like a holiday, and the locals are debased by the fighting on their soil is unique to the Vietnam War. However, while it may be an effective critique of that debacle, it is a strong polemic against all war and more generally, its indictment is of anyone who glorifies a lack of compassion. It is this that the film satirizes, especially in the boot camp that tries to take away agency and free will. And satire it is; often as much a caricature as Dr. Strangelove and as exaggerated as A Clockwork Orange. Our only heroes are those who strain to maintain a sense of humanity and it provides a fitting bookend, not only to the film, but to Kubrick cinematic career, that the last act shown is someone regaining his sense of agency in the small way left available to him.

This is one of the best war (or anti-war) films that I have seen. It is a tale told in two parts. In the first part we follow green recruits as they go through basic training on Parris Island. It is the first part of the story that introduces us to two truly unforgettable characters: Drill Instructor Hartman is a terrifying figure who uses both verbal and physical abuse to mold his men into Marines. Hartman is superbly played by real-life ex-Marine R. Lee Ermey, and not a single word of his seems fake or contrived. The second unforgettable character is Pvt. Leonard Lawrence, better known as Pyle. From the first time you see him on screen you get the feeling that something isn't right. The overweight recruit takes the worst of Hartman's abuse, is humiliated, betrayed by a friend and finally completely broken down until he becomes the picture of quiet madness. The first part of the story ends with a shocking act of violence that shows what can happen when you ask ordinary men to become killing machines.The second part of the story finds Joker (the character who narrates the film) in Vietnam, now a Sergeant and a writer for Stars and Stripes. His job is not as much about reporting the truth as it is about boosting morale. Joker is a walking contradiction, a Marine who wears a peace button, yet has "BORN TO KILL" written on his helmet. In this part of the story we meet another memorable character, Animal Mother, an unbalanced individual who while standing over the bodies of two fallen comrades says without emotion, "Better you than me". The last shots of Marines marching through fiery ruins while singing the Mickey Mouse Club theme song could best be described as haunting. If war is hell, then these are the damned.A great script, great cinematography, a solid cast and a good soundtrack all brought together by a great director. This film stands above all other Vietnam War movies, rivaled only by Francis Ford Coppola's Apocalypse Now. Full Metal Jacket is a film that everyone should see at least once, although it retains it's power even after repeated viewings. A truly great film

Full Metal Jacket is a classic movie about the Vietnam War. It is made by Stantley Kubrick, my personal favorite director, and therefore has many of Kubrick's trademark styles. The movie (for me, at least) consists of three parts. The first part is about the marine's  boot camp. The second part is all of the action and battles in Vietnam. The third part is about the main character's battle with a lone sniper hidden in a building.
Part one is definitely where the movie shines. The boot camp scenes are the undisputed best scenes in the movie. Kubrick really gets to display and showcase his incredible talent as a director. Examples are how there's perfect symmetry with the beds and the footlockers in the men's rooms. It's so perfect, it's practically jaw-dropping. We also get to meet Drill Sgt. Hartman. He's so over-the-top and hillarious that you can't help to get sucked into the movie. Vietnam veterans that saw this movie and said that the boot camp scenes were incredibly realistic.
Part two doesn't live up to the perfection of part one. In part two, Full Metal Jacket turns into an average war movie. Kubrick shows off less of his skills in part two, and several montages of battles are shown. It's still great action and well-directed, but it's dissapointing to see such a wonderful movie become so..average.
Part three is the last thirty minutes of the movie. Kubrick's talent is able to shine again in this part. Every shot by the sniper becomes very cinematic, and is shown in slow-motion. This gives the movie a more gritty and grueling feel. You can almost feel the pain that the soldier's feel when they struck by the bullets. The ending of the movie is very satisfying and shows that this is more than your average war movie.
In summary, Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket is a very well-made movie. It's a classic that is very thrilling and very fun to watch. I'd recommend this movie to anyone that is interesting in war movies or the Vietnam War itself.

Full Metal Jacket is often described as 'uneven'.  I agree.  On the whole, many (re)viewers consider the first act meticulous, the second aimless, and the third farcical (or adjectives to similar effect).  I have no issue with such assessments.  Occasionally, a review will tie these observations together and make the assertion that Stanley Kubrick lost his way and made a total mess of the movie.  That's where I have to disagree.

Kubrick was nothing if not an extremely competent filmmaker.  Others might be rightly accused of ineptitude, but in his films, the absence (or presence) of anything onscreen is unquestionably intentional.

In that light, I see the first act (the Parris Island training) as an indoctrination not only for the draftees, but for the audience.  At the end of the training we, like Joker and company, will be prepared for what's to come.  We'll have 'squared our shit away' in an organized fashion, and our constitution will be a clear, highly polished, meticulously crafted reconstruction of our former naive perspective.  At the end of the training, our inner child (Pyle) will be dead, along with the architect of our re-creation (Hartman), whose continued presence would stand in the way of claiming this new vision as our own.

The irony of the second act is that our newly sharpened senses are focused on the ambiguous mess that is the lot of a correspondent in Da Nang.  While a perfectly serviceable war rages all around, we're sentenced to a menial existence taking handshake shots for the newspapers, chasing 'bush' shots at USO shows, and coming up with clever articles carefully crafted to convey just the right impression about what's going on around us.  Danger consists of a negotiation with a hooker going wrong, and we yearn for a chance to 'get out in the shit' and do what we came here to do.

War comes to town in the third act in the form of the Tet Offensive, and finally we can get down to the mission we've come to conduct.  It's a cheat, though, and we learn that in the business of war there are no winners, no losers, no glory, no real indignity, and especially no John Wayne on point to lead us to victory, just the slogging and the grinding and the merciless pounding of war like a sledgehammer on the anthill we inhabit.

All our preparation has been for naught.  It was all pointless.  And that's where I so often find myself with Kubrick's movies.

By removing the last chapter of Anthony Burgess's original novella, Kubrick cheats Alex of an epilogue in which he abandons his destructiveness, and leaves him a deterministic psychopath.  Kubrick's Jack Torrance arrives at the Overlook Hotel unbalanced and spirals into a fatalistic void, bereft of the good nature Stephen King imbues him with at the start of his novel, and denied the redemption he achieves at its end.

Kubrick didn't even have to tailor the original content in this case.  Hasford's 'Short Timers' came as ready-made grist for the nihilistic mill that would become Full Metal Jacket.  A reliable source can be quoted as saying there is no point.  Their observations of life's horrendous insensibility prove it.  Nothing you can conjure, let alone accomplish, will make any difference.

Seems a bit sterile to me.  I'm not saying the movie should have been made to my order, but it would have been nice if it'd said something!  As it stands, not even the film is aspiring to overcome the futility of it all, which in my mind absolves me of any responsibility for investing the effort in  it.

So at the end of it all, Full Metal Jacket is like the prettiest present under the tree, wrapped most meticulously in the most beautiful paper and adorned with the most impressive bow.  After all the excitement of unwrapping it, however, it's just an empty box, and even THAT (as near as I can tell) isn't supposed to mean anything.

As many of you may know, this film is split very distinctly in two halves.  The first being basic training for new marines, and the second being an excerpt from Joker's service around the time of the Tet Offensive.

The first half is generally everyone's favorite, because it represents what war can do to someone even before they reach battle.  Also, of course, because of Sergeant Hartman, brilliantly portrayed by R. Lee Ermey.  While many would like to credit Kubrick's story for this part, I feel that at least 75% of it's greatness is owed to Ermey, as he either wrote or improvised every line of his dialogue.  This part of the film creates a complex emotional mood, as Hartman gives the audience laughs mixed with sudden anxiety and grief due to the things he says to his recruits.  Also, some will laugh at lines others don't such as when he tells Private Pyle "if God wanted you at the top of that wall he would've miracled your ass up there."  

It's a very valid argument to say that this half could have been a movie by itself, if extended to show more scenes of recruits on downtime, etc.  However, I feel that this would have detracted from the mood.  The engrossing nature of this part of the film is due mainly to the feeling that the marines are always training, and are relentlessly under the pressuring watch of Sergeant Hartman.

The second half of the film shows a portion of Joker's service, which is initially relaxed but is quickly interrupted by the Tet Offensive.  This portion attempts to represent what being at war was like, even if it isn't in the absolute worst part of battle.

So why is the movie split, and why will it probably seem a bit unsatisfying on the first viewing?  Because it wasn't meant to be a Hollywood version of Vietnam, but rather the real version.  I originally thought this movie was far fetched, but I've since learned that it is one of the most accurate depictions ever made.  A friend of mine's father, who fought in Vietnam, couldn't watch FMJ because it was too real.  I also had a neighbor who confirmed the attitude of the film, that a soldier is (or at least was) trained to think nothing of taking human life. Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket is one of the greatest and most honest films about war ever made. Descending neither to the level of gung-ho shoot-'em-up or self righteous anti-war screed, it instead earnestly tells the unflinching truth about the hell that is war, and how men deal with it. In following one James T. "Joker" Davis (Matthew Modine) on his journey from wide-eyed recruit on Parris Island to battle hardened veteran in the battlefields of Vietnam, it shows us what it means to be an American soldier in wartime.
	The first thing you should understand about this movie is that Kubrick does nothing halfway. Instead of a half-baked montage of training scenes as music blares, we spend nearly half the movie on watching the characters go through the Corps' basic training beginning to end. The drill sergeant (real life Marine Corps drill instructor R. Lee Emery) uses language that will make polite company spontaneously burst into flames. When a man is hit by bullets, red sprays in every direction. And when someone takes a life for the first time, you will see their face harden as a part of them changes forever.
The second thing to understand is that Kubrick is not interested in protesting our involvement in Vietnam, demonizing our leaders a la Oliver Stone, or making our soldiers into traumatized, debauched frat-boys a la Jarhead, but neither does he have any intention of shying away from hard truths. Full Metal Jacket is completely open about the fact that a large part of military training is taking away any qualms you have about killing, including making you see the enemy as less than human. It frankly acknowledges that when one of our boys got a come-on from a whore, his first response was most likely "How much?" And it does not try to make combat look glorious, heroic, or anything else but terrifying and bloody.
Thirdly, this movie wants you to understand that despite the dehumanizing effects of what they go through, our troops are still thinking, feeling human beings. They understand that they are in hell, and that every day could be their last. They turn to humor, nihilism, false bravado, or their fellow soldiers. Some men find ways to distance themselves from the insanity of their situations. Others, like Joker, embrace the contradictions of their existence. And at the end of the day, each man is just glad to be alive.
Some have complained that the second half of the film is shapeless, and lacks an overarching narrative.  And they're right. Except for the presence of Joker, and the setting in Vietnam, there is no common thread holding these scenes together. But that's the point. The second half isn't about a battle, or how America lost the war. It is simply a record of one man's experiences in Vietnam.  Real life doesn't follow a set plotline, with rising action, false crisis, false dawn, real crisis, resolution, and maybe a twist or two that no-one saw coming. A combat tour is not always a journey of personal development and self discovery, and it is rarely a series of ever more dangerous missions culminating in an explosive climax. 
There have also been complaints that the film's message was 'muddled' or that its message was too little too late.  Some of this criticism comes from critics I greatly respect. But once again, they are missing the point. Full Metal Jacket is not an 'issue' movie, or a 'message' movie. It is not for or against the Vietnam War. It seeks neither to glorify war and justify our actions in Vietnam, or to preach about the evils of war and why it must be avoided at all costs. It only seeks to show the reality of combat.
 And I suspect that for some critics, this is the sticking point. They want a clear stand on the morality of the war, preferably against it. I can understand this. Many of them were proud participants in the anti-war movement. They want to hear Kubrick, who for many of them is practically an idol, agree with their views. Or like a college professor grading a student's essay, they want to know "Just what is your position on the subject?" But part of the beauty of Full Metal Jacket is that it doesn't take a side or tell us what to think. It doesn't want to advocate a position or alter our opinion on the war. It only wants to show us the reality of it.
So if you watch this movie, do not expect nonstop action and heroics, discussions about the wisdom of American foreign policy in Southeast Asia, or even a unifying plotline for much of the film. But expect to gain a greater appreciation for those who have been through the hell that is war. And expect to be impressed.

Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket is slightly different to the vast majority of Vietnam War movies in a sense that the action does not fully take place in Vietnam but spends half the time at boot camp at the Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island. Full Metal Jacket follows a platoon of US marines through the dehumanising and brainwashing effects of boot camp to the traumatic effects of the Vietnam War. Similarly too many other works of Kubrick, Full Metal Jacket is a dark satire but this time on war. The opening act at boot camp is darkly brutal but at the exact same time darkly funny. R. Lee Ermey (who plays Gunnery Sergeant Hartman) in his mostly improvised role, is fantastic delivering an endless array of quotable lines. The dehumanising effects and brainwashing that are clearly evident is disturbing and shocking as the marines are insulted and made to feel worthless. Much has been said that the first half is by far superior to the second half but this does not turn out to be entirely true.  The second half is full of tension (the sniper sequence is excellent), expertly staged war sequences (the urban warfare sequences are intense) and some marvellous cinematography (which was actually shot in England). The performances are sensational, particularly from Vincent D'Onofrio and Matthew Modine, the soundtrack is awesome (featuring Nancy Sinatra and the Rolling Stones) and Kubrick's anti war film leaves you with one major message-War is hell.

A guerra do Vietnã é vista pela ótica de Kubrick em uma das obras mais marcantes já produzidas sobre o assunto. Nascido para Matar é obviamente dividido em dois atos - o primeiro, superior, mostra um grupo de recrutas da marinha sob o rigoroso treinamento fascista do Sgt. Hartman (em fantástica interpretação de R. Lee Ermey). Algo incomum em sua obra, Kubrick cria um personagem que estabelece uma relação direta com o espectador através do malfadado soldado Pyle (Vincent D'Onofrio). Seu sofrimento e sentimento de exclusão preparam o terreno para a segunda parte da narrativa, na qual vemos as máquinas de matar na qual os recrutas foram transformados.

Enquanto a segunda metade da película acabe muitas vezes caindo no lugar comum de tantos outros filmes de guerra (propulsionado também pela falta de um protagonista marcante), o desenrolar dos momentos finais é especialmente impactante. A vertente de Kubrick ainda se mostra neutra, mostrando os efeitos devastadores do conflito (mais em termos psicológicos do que físicos), mas evitando criar uma obra condescendente ou moralista.
